titleproper.value:
Guide to the Michael Harrington Papers
                    <num>TAM.209</num>

author.value: Finding aid prepared by Peter Filardo

creation.value:
This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit
                <date>2012-03-29T19:01-0400</date>

abstract.label: Abstract
abstract.value:
Michael Harrington (1928-1989) was a U.S. socialist, editor, writer, founder and leader of Democratic Socialists of America (U.S. affiliate to the Socialist International), and political leader best known for his book 
                <title render="italic">The Other America: Poverty in the United States</title>(1962). These papers include his notebooks, correspondence, and documentation of his various political and journalistic endeavors.

p.value:
Published citations should take the following form: 
                <lb/>
                <lb/>Identification of item, date; Collection name; Collection number; box number; folder number; 
                <lb/>Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives 
                <lb/>Elmer Holmes Bobst Library 
                <lb/>70 Washington Square South 
                <lb/>New York, NY 10012, New York University Libraries.

<bibref>
                    <emph render="italic">See also</emph>: Isserman, Maurice, 
                    <title render="italic">The Other American : The Life of Michael Harrington</title>(New York : Public Affairs, 2000), 449 p.</bibref>

Series two, arranged alphabetically by topic, contains typescripts for unpublished and published articles, book reviews, lectures, speeches, and for a debate with Carl Gershman, typescripts for 
                <title render="italic">The New American Poverty</title>(1984) and 
                <title render="italic">Socialism, Past and Future</title>(partial, 1989), three oral history interview transcripts (1965, 1988), documents from and unpublished Harrington reports on several Socialist International leadership meetings, including one discussing the Palestine Liberation Organization (1979), additional reading notes, publishing and miscellaneous correspondence, clippings, materials relating to Harrington's teaching career, U.S. Senate testimony (1987), and an invitation to the funeral of Robert F. Kennedy.
